title: 103_s1249
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993". Between 10,000,000 and 15,000,000 people in the United States have been infected with tuberculosis, with nearly 26,000 new cases reported each year and over 1,700 deaths annually. The number of reported cases has increased from 22,201 in 1985 to 26,673 in 1992. Drug-resistant tuberculosis strains can be costly to treat, with a high mortality rate. In 1992, cases were reported in all 50 states, with drug-resistant cases in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In 1992, tuberculosis cases reported in at least 36 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. 27 percent of cases occurred in foreign-born persons. One third of the world's population harbors tuberculosis. Tuberculosis remains the number one killer among infectious diseases worldwide, with 8,000,000 new cases and 2,900,000 deaths annually. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act allocates funding for tuberculosis prevention and control services. States applying for grants must submit a plan showing how funds will be used to provide services to high-risk populations or areas with high infection rates. The applicant must collaborate with and support entities receiving funds. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act requires states to submit plans for grant funding allocation towards tuberculosis prevention and control services. Plans must show collaboration with entities receiving funds and focus on providing services to populations with high infection rates. Additionally, the Secretary may conduct research and training to support these grants. The Secretary may conduct or support research and training for tuberculosis prevention and control grants, with authorized appropriations of $26,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for subsequent years. A technical amendment removes a sentence from the Public Health Service Act. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases conducts research and training for tuberculosis prevention and control grants with authorized appropriations. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases conducts research and training for tuberculosis prevention and control grants with authorized appropriations totaling $46,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for subsequent years. The Food and Drug Administration will implement a tuberculosis drug and device research program with a $5,000,000 annual budget. This program includes assisting other agencies in developing tuberculosis protocols, evaluating medical devices for tuberculosis diagnosis and control, and conducting research on drugs and devices for tuberculosis prevention.
